sources.full: Obojima: Tales from the Tall Grass (2024)

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (blue, about 6-7 feet tall) or Small (red, about 2-3 feet tall), chosen when you select this species

entries.name: Awakened Skills
entries: You gain proficiency in three skills of your choice.

entries.name: Create Talisman
entries: As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can create a paper talisman, which can bestow unique abilities upon any creature in possession of it. When you do so, choose an option from the Talisman Forms table. The talisman lasts for 1 hour or until it is activated. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.
Some talismans can only be taken by dara of certain colors.
This information can be found in the Talisman Form table.

entries.name: Talisman Forms
rows: When a creature in possession of this talisman is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} but not killed outright, the talisman activates, causing the creature to drop to 1 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} instead.
When a creature in possession of this talisman makes an ability check, it can activate the talisman to add {@dice 1d6} to the check. The creature can roll the die before or after making the check.
When a creature in possession of this talisman makes a saving throw, it can activate the talisman to add {@dice 1d6} to the save. The creature can roll the die before or after making the save.
When this talisman is created, it is bound to a weapon you are holding. The next time this weapon hits a target, the talisman activates, dealing extra Radiant damage equal to your character level.

A creature in possession of this talisman can use its {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to activate the talisman, granting it the benefit of the {@action Dash|XPHB} or {@action Disengage|XPHB} action (its choice).

entries.name: Sacred Revelation
entries: You possess an innate gift that allows you to perceive and absorb information from the peculiar glyphs scattered across the island. These glyphs take the form of intricate symbols resembling thumbprints and hold the potential to convey anything from simple messages to complex skills to you. As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can touch and absorb any information stored inside one of these glyphs.

entries.name: Impart Knowledge
entries: In dara culture, individuals who obtain wisdom truly worth sharing are blessed with a unique ability to impart glyphs before their death. This extraordinary skill is revered among the dara.

When you reach character level 10, you gain the ability to impart messages through dara glyphs. As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can press your hand against any surface and create a unique thumbprint-shaped glyph. When you create this glyph, you recite a message, which is stored inside the magical symbol. The glyph can be seen by only other dara and can be absorbed only by using the Sacred Revelation ability.

items.name: Create Talisman (Blue Dara)
entries: As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can create a paper talisman, which can bestow unique abilities upon any creature in possession of it. When you do so, choose an option from the Talisman Forms table. The talisman lasts for 1 hour or until it is activated. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.
Some talismans can only be taken by dara of certain colors.
This information can be found in the Talisman Form table.

When this talisman is created, it is bound to a weapon you are holding. The next time this weapon hits a target, the talisman activates, dealing extra Radiant damage equal to your character level.

A creature in possession of this talisman can use its {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to activate the talisman, granting it the benefit of the {@action Dash|XPHB} or {@action Disengage|XPHB} action (its choice).

entries: As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can create a paper talisman, which can bestow unique abilities upon any creature in possession of it. When you do so, choose an option from the Talisman Forms table. The talisman lasts for 1 hour or until it is activated. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.
Some talismans can only be taken by dara of certain colors.
This information can be found in the Talisman Form table.

rows: When a creature in possession of this talisman is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} but not killed outright, the talisman activates, causing the creature to drop to 1 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} instead.
When a creature in possession of this talisman makes a saving throw, it can activate the talisman to add {@dice 1d6} to the save. The creature can roll the die before or after making the save.
When this talisman is created, it is bound to a weapon you are holding. The next time this weapon hits a target, the talisman activates, dealing extra Radiant damage equal to your character level.

A creature in possession of this talisman can use its {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to activate the talisman, granting it the benefit of the {@action Dash|XPHB} or {@action Disengage|XPHB} action (its choice).

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Ethereal Sight
entries: You can use a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to shift your sight, allowing you to see creatures in the Spirit Realm, which appear as glowing outlines of themselves. This effect lasts for 1 hour. You can use this trait a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Oaka Mark
entries: Your connection to the Spirit Realm manifests as a birthmark that grants you supernatural abilities. Choose an option from the Oaka Marks table. You know the cantrip specified at level 1 for that mark.

When you reach character levels 3 and 5, you learn a higher-level spell, as shown on the table. You always have that spell prepared. You can cast it once without expending a spell slot or needing Material components, and you regain the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast the spell using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level.
Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for the spells you cast with this trait (choose the ability when you select the mark).

items.name: Oaka Mark (Courage)
entries: Your connection to the Spirit Realm manifests as a birthmark that grants you supernatural abilities. You know the {@spell Resistance|XPHB} cantrip.

When you reach character level 3, you learn the {@spell Heroism|XPHB} spell. When you reach character level 5, you also learn the {@spell At Your Side|ObojimaTallGrass24} spell. You always have these spells prepared, and you can cast each spell once without a spell slot. Once you cast either of these spells with this trait, you can't cast that spell with it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast the spell using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level.
Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for the spells you cast with this trait (choose the ability when you select the mark).

items.name: Oaka Mark (Fury)
entries: Your connection to the Spirit Realm manifests as a birthmark that grants you supernatural abilities. You know the {@spell Sacred Flame|XPHB} cantrip.

When you reach character level 3, you learn the {@spell Bane|XPHB} spell. When you reach character level 5, you also learn the {@spell Shatter|XPHB} spell. You always have these spells prepared, and you can cast each spell once without a spell slot. Once you cast either of these spells with this trait, you can't cast that spell with it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast the spell using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level.
Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for the spells you cast with this trait (choose the ability when you select the mark).

items.name: Oaka Mark (Harmony)
entries: Your connection to the Spirit Realm manifests as a birthmark that grants you supernatural abilities. You know the {@spell Guidance|XPHB} cantrip.

When you reach character level 3, you learn the {@spell Pacify Person|ObojimaTallGrass24} spell. When you reach character level 5, you also learn the {@spell Calm Emotions|XPHB} spell. You always have these spells prepared, and you can cast each spell once without a spell slot. Once you cast either of these spells with this trait, you can't cast that spell with it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast the spell using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level.
Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for the spells you cast with this trait (choose the ability when you select the mark).

items.name: Oaka Mark (Nature)
entries: Your connection to the Spirit Realm manifests as a birthmark that grants you supernatural abilities. You know the {@spell Dancing Lights|XPHB} cantrip.

When you reach character level 3, you learn the {@spell Sprout Foliage|ObojimaTallGrass24} spell. When you reach character level 5, you also learn the {@spell Animal Messenger|XPHB} spell. You always have these spells prepared, and you can cast each spell once without a spell slot. Once you cast either of these spells with this trait, you can't cast that spell with it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast the spell using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level.
Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for the spells you cast with this trait (choose the ability when you select the mark).

items.name: Oaka Mark (Purity)
entries: Your connection to the Spirit Realm manifests as a birthmark that grants you supernatural abilities. You know the {@spell Spare the Dying|XPHB} cantrip.

When you reach character level 3, you learn the {@spell Cure Wounds|XPHB} spell. When you reach character level 5, you also learn the {@spell Lesser Restoration|XPHB} spell. You always have these spells prepared, and you can cast each spell once without a spell slot. Once you cast either of these spells with this trait, you can't cast that spell with it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast the spell using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level.
Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for the spells you cast with this trait (choose the ability when you select the mark).

items.name: Oaka Mark (Selflessness)
entries: Your connection to the Spirit Realm manifests as a birthmark that grants you supernatural abilities. You know the {@spell Resilient Friendship|ObojimaTallGrass24} cantrip.

When you reach character level 3, you learn the {@spell Gift|ObojimaTallGrass24} spell. When you reach character level 5, you also learn the {@spell Warding Bond|XPHB} spell. You always have these spells prepared, and you can cast each spell once without a spell slot. Once you cast either of these spells with this trait, you can't cast that spell with it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast the spell using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level.
Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for the spells you cast with this trait (choose the ability when you select the mark).

entries.name: Amphibious
entries: The nakudama can breathe air and water.

entries.name: Grasping Tongue
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can lash out your tongue at an object you can see within 15 feet of you that weighs no more than 5 pounds and pull it to you, catching it in your open hand or allowing it to fall at your feet. If the object is being worn or carried by a creature, that creature must succeed on a Strength saving throw (DC 8 plus your Strength modifier and {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}) or have the object pulled away from it.

entries.name: Latching Tongue
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can extend your tongue to latch onto a surface or creature that is at least one size larger than you, pulling yourself toward it. The target must be no more than 15 feet away from you.

entries.name: Standing Leap
entries: Your {@variantrule Long Jump|XPHB} is up to 20 feet, and your {@variantrule High Jump|XPHB} is up to 15 feet, with or without a running start.

raceFluff.name: Dara
entries: Dara are a mysterious people that emerged from the forests of Obojima less than 300 years ago. No one knows if they are from Obojima itself or if they came from another realm. Even the dara themselves speculate as to their origin, though most believe they are all descendents of an enigmatic figure known as the {@i First Dara}. What is known about the dara is that they are insatiably curious, a gift they claim is from their progenitor. Dara often gravitate toward being wanderers, seeking out anything that interests them, and many scrawl notes and sketches as they are observing. It's hard to know what a dara will be fascinated by next, as they are just as interested in a small bug trundling over a leaf as they are a sinuous dragon flying through the sky.

entries.name: A Message From the Past
entries: Dara possess a unique gift—the ability to absorb a vast amount of information in an instant through contact with a magical glyph. These magical symbols, which resemble large finger-prints, are found on trees throughout Obojima and can only be seen by dara. A dara who touches one of these glyphs taps into its reservoir of knowledge. Through it, a dara could learn not just information, but also new skills. It is widely believed that many of these glyphs were left by the First Dara to guide future generations.

entries.name: Dara Lifecycle
entries: It's widely understood that one dara's life begins where another ends. When a dara is about to die, their final act is to capture what remains of their soul and store it into a single glyph, which they place upon a tree. Known as a parting glyph, it is imbued with the dying dara's identity, memories, and skills. There, the glyph waits until it can be claimed by a new dara.

A dara is born from the earth, emerging into Obojima, fully formed, through the roots of a tree that bears a parting glyph. Most are born from trees in the sacred grove in Roa Kala, the ancestral homeland of the dara (see page 122 for more on Roa Kala), but it could be anywhere a dara has died. When a dara leaves the soil, they are a blank slate, aware and without identity until they touch the parting glyph found at the base of their tree.

Parting glyphs give young dara a set of intellectual tools to function. In the form of memories, the glyphs offer the previous dara's perspective about a world yet to be experienced. For many dara, the parting glyph leads them to Roa Kala and from there they choose their new life.

entries.name: The Color of Dara
entries: Dara come in two distinct forms, with many unique features between them, but most refer to them by their color: blue or red. here are no social differences between blue and red dara, and they seem to appear in equal numbers. The origin of the two types is unknown, though there is a belief among them that the First Dara looked like an amalgamation of both types.

entries.name: Blue Dara
entries: Blue dara are usually between 6 and 7 feet tall, with bluehued skin and a single large eye found in the middle of their head. Their body is completely devoid of hair and they're normally quite stout.
As a blue dara you gain the use of the Knowledge Talisman and are able to produce it once per day in addition to other talismans you know.

entries.name: Red Dara
entries: Red dara are much shorter, with an average height between 2 and 3 feet tall. In addition to their smaller stature, they are easily distinguished from their larger kin by the bright red hue of their skin and their two eyes.
As a red dara you gain the use of the Might Talisman and are able to produce it once per day in addition to other talismans you know.

entries.name: Age
entries: From the moment dara pop into existence they have all basic motor functions mastered. By the time a month has passed they are a fully functioning member of society. It's unknown how long a dara can live for, but the average is roughly 100 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Dara tend to lead slow-paced observant lives. Their natural curiosity and desire to learn often leads them down a life as passive bystanders. They're not easily swayed and tend to stay neutral both in conflict and life.

raceFluff.name: Elf
entries: The elves of Obojima possess a deep and special bond with the enigmatic Spirit Realm and its native spirits. Unlike other inhabitants of the island, elves do not form distinct communities or enclaves, as they are not a people in the traditional sense. This is because elves are born to human parents. While uncommon, this occurrence is not so rare that it provokes disdain or apprehension. Instead, it's simply understood that an elf exists with one foot in two worlds.

entries.name: Marked by the Spirits
entries: Every elf shares common physical traits such as pointed ears and a keen ability to see in the dark. What sets an Obojima elf apart, however, is the presence of an Oaka Mark—a unique symbol that represents their profound bond with the Spirit Realm. Each of these mystical glyphs appears as a shimmering birthmark that can range from the size of a coin to covering an entire limb. More than a mere physical marker, the Oaka Mark holds deep significance for elves—and may even bestow unique supernatural abilities.

entries.name: Spirit Guide by Circumstance
entries: Throughout the ages, the islanders and spirits have coexisted harmoniously, although it would be misleading to claim that they always agree on everything. Consequently, elves often find themselves acting as intermediaries when conflicts arise between spirits and folk from the Physical Realm.

entries.name: Age
entries: Elves reach adulthood in their late teens and live less than a century. Though they have unique gifts, their physical fortitude and longevity are equal to those of humans.

entries.name: Fading Gift
entries: With each passing year, the birth of elves becomes less and less common. Though this slow decline hasn't caused much alarm— being difficult to notice—many mages and scholars wonder if the day will come when the last elf is born to Obojima. This sorrowful outcome remains a possibility that future generations may have to face. Those who dwell on such grim thoughts still leave room for hope, believing that Obojima itself might intervene before that day arrives.

Although elves aren't too dissimilar from humans, their eccentricities can serve as a powerful storytelling tool. We strongly encourage you, as a GM, to explore an elf's connection to the Spirit Realm—how spirits might gravitate towards them, or how companions might seek an elf's help over that of a human or nakudama. The rarity of elves in the world of Obojima should not go unnoticed by the spirits around them.

raceFluff.name: Nakudama
entries: A sweet treat left untasted, a hot spring left undipped in, a warm fire left unshared—all considered tragedies by a people driven to indulge in all the comforts and curiosities Obojima has to offer. To the other peoples of the island, the amphibious nakudama seem to partake in all things with a sense of eagerness and excitement.

Nakudama tend to eschew enclaves for the more cosmopolitan settlements scattered across the island. They are highly social. Patrons of tea houses, taverns, and inns are sure to hear the booming, croaking voices of nakudama mingling with crowds.

entries.name: Did I Ever Tell You the Story About…
entries: Life is too short to spend time on anything not worth recounting in an over-the-top tale later. Sharing and collecting stories is among the most cherished nakudama traditions. It's what motivates many nakudama to travel the island or frequent social gatherings. A quality story doesn't just happen, however. Any nakudama will tell you it's one part lived experience and two parts showmanship—which includes creative license and allows for at least a bit of exaggeration. The art can be practiced, but experience must be earned. Therefore, nakudama tend to venture out regularly in search of novel stories to share.

entries.name: Obojima's Earliest Inhabitants
entries: Though the details have been lost to history or exaggerated over years of storytelling, it is generally believed that the nakudama were the first people to call Obojima home. Several sites around the island point to an ancient nakudama civilization, and many settlements appear to incorporate nakudama architecture, which is noteworthy for its water features.

Other evidence that suggests an earlier Nakudama Age comes from their tales, which are filled with the fantastical feats of a powerful nakudama queen. Though often overly dramatic in her portrayals, her exploits seem to line up with recent archaeological findings.

entries.name: Age
entries: Young nakudama learn to walk and swim in shallow waters just a few weeks after birth. They reach adulthood by the age of 10 and live an average of 45 years.

entries.name: Naku Naku
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and {@language Naku Naku|ObojimaTallGrass24}.

subclass.name: Path of the Belly Brewer
subclassFeatures: Path of the Belly Brewer|Barbarian|XPHB|Belly Brewer|ObojimaTallGrass24|3

subclass.name: Sheep Dragon Shepherd
subclassFeatures: Take to the Skies|Monk|XPHB|Sheep Dragon Shepherd|ObojimaTallGrass24|11
Guide to the Herd|Monk|XPHB|Sheep Dragon Shepherd|ObojimaTallGrass24|17

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Belly Brewer
entries: These Barbarians are masters of brewing potions on the fly—directly in their guts! While others must painstakingly prepare potions with finesse, Belly Brewers channel their inner hunger to unlock the latent magic within raw ingredients without any preparation.

Those born with the rumble in their belly often find that regular food can't quite satisfy—they require something more unusual. A generation ago, a handful of adventurous eaters with "the appetite" set out to find a way to appease their seemingly insatiable hunger. This is how they discovered "belly brewing." When certain morsels were consumed together, they not only quieted the rumble for a time but also yielded the potion-like effects that Belly Brewers have since come to be known for.

subclassFeature.name: Belly Concoction
entries: You learn the hard-earned skill of belly brewing, an arcane technique in which you swallow, mix, and brew magical concoctions inside your gut to create a number of unique effects.

When you enter your {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian|XPHB|1}, you focus your energy to harness and activate the effects of a belly concoction. Choose one of the following types of belly concoctions: Combat, Utility, or Whimsy. You gain the benefits associated with the chosen type, as detailed below. You can change your belly concoction to a different type each time you enter your Rage.

entries.name: Combat
entries: Your body undergoes a unique change, which magically alters your physical form, giving it the characteristics of rubber. While in this elastic state, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} when you are hit by a ranged attack, deflecting it with your belly. When you do so, the damage you take from the attack is reduced by {@dice 1d12} plus your Constitution modifier and Barbarian level. Additionally, immediately before you make a melee attack roll with a weapon or an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB} on your turn, you can take a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to stretch your arms, increasing your reach by 5 feet for the rest of the turn. The first time you hit a target while your arms are stretched in this way, the attack deals an extra {@damage 1d6} damage of the weapon's type.

entries.name: Utility
entries: The bubbling elixir in your stomach is perfectly mixed to dissolve and absorb anything you are able to swallow. As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can consume any object that can fit in your mouth. If the object isn't a magic item, you can expend one of your {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Dice} as part of this {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to heal yourself. Roll the die and add your Constitution modifier; you regain a number of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the total (minimum of 1). Swallowing an object in this way destroys it, provided it isn't magical. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Constitution modifier, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Whimsy
entries: You focus on the magical brew inside you, only to exhibit an array of strange and unruly effects. While in this state, you gain one of the following effects of your choice at the start of each of your turns:

items: You teleport to an unoccupied space you can see within 10 feet of you.
You take {@damage 1d4} Necrotic damage; the next ability check you make before the end of your turn gains a bonus equal to the number rolled.

You can immediately take the {@action Help|XPHB} action as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}. Additionally, you gain a random visual effect that accompanies the other whimsical features. For example, your hair might turn to moss, a spectral bird might circle above your head, or a tattoo of a dancing man might appear on your skin and move about your body.

subclassFeature.name: Side Effects
entries: You gain a number of magical side effects due to the countless magical ingredients you've ingested. You know the {@spell Prestidigitation} and {@spell Thaumaturgy} cantrips. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

subclassFeature.name: Quick Brew
entries: You've learned how to better control the effects your belly concoction produces. Choose a {@filter common potion|items|source=|type=potion|rarity=common|category=|miscellaneous=} that one would normally consume. You can activate the effects of the chosen potion as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}. Once you activate it, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. If the potion's effects require a saving throw, the DC equals 8 plus your Constitution modifier and {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}.
Whenever you gain a Barbarian level, you can replace your chosen potion with a different one, provided it is also a common potion that one would normally consume.

An alternate way of using this feature is to allow the player to choose only from the potion recipes they know. If the Belly Brewer hasn't learned any potion recipes, the GM should provide a list of ten options to choose from.

subclassFeature.name: Lingering Effects
entries: The ever-present concoction in your stomach is now so potent it grants you benefits even when you aren't {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian|XPHB|1||raging}. When you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, choose one of the following conditions: {@condition Blinded}, {@condition Charmed}, {@condition Exhaustion}, {@condition Frightened}, {@condition Paralyzed}, {@condition Petrified}, {@condition Poisoned}, {@condition Prone}, {@condition Restrained}, or {@condition Stunned}. You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against that condition until you choose a different one with this feature.

subclassFeature.name: Mighty Quick Brew
entries: You learn an additional {@filter common potion|items|source=|type=potion|rarity=common|category=|miscellaneous=} as well as an {@filter uncommon potion|items|source=|type=potion|rarity=uncommon|category=|miscellaneous=}, using your {@subclassFeature Quick Brew|Barbarian|XPHB|Belly Brewer|ObojimaTallGrass24|6} feature. Whenever you gain a Barbarian level, you can replace one of these potions with a different one, provided it is also a common or uncommon potion, respectively, that one would normally consume.

subclassFeature.name: College of Masks
entries: To be a Bard from the College of Masks is to be a theater actor capable of losing themselves in a role by using masks they imbue with magic. Through these masks, Bards can mimic others and even take on attributes of the personas their masks depict.

To see the world through another's eyes. To show the world a face not your own. To become someone else. These are the actor's pursuits. Some local players might putter about on the stage as a hobby or distraction, but not Bards of the College of Masks. Like liquid bronze being poured into a mold, these actors have turned their sense of self into a malleable thing able to transform themselves into someone else.

entries.name: Tradition of Performance
entries: The College of Masks not only describes the Bard but also refers to an Obojiman theater tradition in which a solitary masked actor plays out a story from the island's myths and folktales. These stories feature a set of archetypal characters such as the Old Man, the Fish, and the Demon, among others. Throughout the show, the actor artfully shifts between masks depicting each character. Each performance offers something special, as no two are ever the same.

subclassFeature.name: Tools of Performance
entries: You gain the ability to weave arcane boons into theater masks, which grant you abilities while you wear them. You craft two masks of your choice from the "Masks" section later in this subclass's description. You craft one additional mask of your choice when you reach Bard levels 7, 11, and 15. Each time you craft a new mask, you can also replace one mask you've already crafted with a different one.

While wearing a mask, you gain the abilities granted by it. You can don or swap masks as a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action or {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}. If an ability from a mask requires a saving throw, the DC equals your Bard spell save DC.

subclassFeature.name: Copycat
entries: You gain the ability to quickly shift your appearance to match that of another person. As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can expend one use of {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard|XPHB|1} to cast the {@spell Alter Self|XPHB} spell, using the spell's Change Appearance option to transform into another Humanoid you have seen. When cast in this way, the spell has the following changes:

items: It doesn't require {@status Concentration|XPHB}.
You gain 5 {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB}, and the spell ends early if you lose all these {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} or die.

You gain new equipment associated with the target and known to be in its possession, such as its clothing, armor, weapons, and other small belongings. Any equipment gained in this way vanishes when the spell ends and has no magical properties, even if the original items used by the target do.

entries: Any equipment you were wearing or carrying merges into your new form, and you can't activate, use, wield, or otherwise benefit from any of it.

subclassFeature.name: Many-Masked Performance
entries: Over the course of 1 minute, you can engage in a captivating performance and attempt to cause nearby creatures to have the {@condition Charmed|XPHB}, {@condition Frightened|XPHB}, or {@condition Unconscious|XPHB} condition (your choice). Choose a number of creatures up to your Bard level within 60 feet of you that can hear you. When the performance ends, each target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your Bard spell save DC or have the chosen condition for 10 minutes. An affected target can repeat the save whenever it takes damage, ending the effect on itself on a success.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Gift of Theater
entries: You gain the ability to give one of your masks from your {@subclassFeature Tools of Performance|Bard|XPHB|Masks|ObojimaTallGrass24|3} feature to an ally within 5 feet of you. As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you temporarily release the incantation that binds the mask to you, allowing one of your allies to use it. The mask can be used in this way for 1 minute, and only one ally can be designated to use it.
Once you've given an ally a mask, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Petal
entries: In the tranquil groves where nature's harmony sings loudest, there exists a circle of Druids attuned to the delicate dance of petals upon the breeze. These Druid guardians of the natural world, known as the Circle of the Petal, draw their power from the spirit of Obojima, the steady island breeze, and the ephemeral beauty and resilience of flowers. Embracing these subtle forces, they harness the whispers of the wind and the gentle caress of petals to weave their enchantments and shape the world around them.

Members of the Circle of the Petal are revered for their deep connection to the sacred dawn petal tree and their ability to evoke its serene splendor in both peaceful sanctuaries and dire situations. These Druids become conduits of life energy, channeling the essence of blossoms into healing balms, protective barriers, and devastating bursts of floral fury. Guided by the eternal cycle of growth, bloom, and decay, they embody the ever-renewing vitality of nature, ensuring that even in the darkest of times, hope blossoms anew like petals on the wind.

subclassFeature.name: Petal Dance
entries: You become permeated with the spirit of Obojima and gain the ability to control a fraction of Obojima's magic, which manifests as flower petals of your choosing. As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can expend a use of {@classFeature Wild Shape|Druid|XPHB|2} to call on this power, conjuring a resilient cloud of petals that functions as an extension of your own being. The cloud lasts for 1 hour. While enveloped by it, you have a +1 bonus to your AC, and you gain the following benefits:

As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can cause your petals to lunge toward a creature you can see within 30 feet of you, slashing at its body. Make a ranged spell attack against the target using your spell attack bonus. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 1d6} Slashing damage. This damage increases by {@dice 1d6} when you reach Druid levels 5 ({@dice 2d6}), 11 ({@dice 3d6}), and 17 ({@dice 4d6}).

When you or a creature you can see within 10 feet of you takes damage, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to reduce the damage by an amount equal to your Druid level plus your Wisdom modifier. Once used in this way, the cloud dissipates.

subclassFeature.name: Petal Beast Mimicry
entries: You gain the ability to imbue life into your petals. As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can summon a spirit that takes the appearance of an animal of your choice. This spirit arrives as a great wind that overtakes the petals before transforming into the desired beast, which you control. The spirit uses the {@creature Wild Spirit|ObojimaTallGrass24} stat block.

The spirit appears in an unoccupied space of your choice within 30 feet of you and acts on your turn. It can only take the {@action Dash|XPHB} and {@action Attack|XPHB} actions. If the spirit is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, it explodes in a stunning spectacle of cascading petals. When this happens, each creature within a 20-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from the spirit is affected by the {@spell Faerie Fire|XPHB} spell until the end of your next turn. Otherwise, the spirit disappears after 1 minute or if you dismiss it early (no action required).

You have two uses of this feature, and you gain an additional use of it when you reach Druid levels 11 (three uses) and 16 (four uses). You regain all expended uses of this feature when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. Starting at Druid level 11, you can expend two uses of this feature to summon two {@creature Wild Spirit|ObojimaTallGrass24|Wild Spirits} instead of one when you take this action.

subclassFeature.name: Spirit of Obojima
entries: The spirit of Obojima comes to your aid in both subtle and grand ways. You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}) checks to find a path or creature, as the wind carries a collection of brilliant white petals in the direction you seek.

Additionally, you can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to create a wall of petals in a space you can see. You can make the wall up to 60 feet long, 15 feet high, and 1 foot thick. It appears in any orientation you choose, as a horizontal or vertical barrier or at an angle. It can be free floating or resting on a solid surface. If the wall cuts through a creature's space when it appears, the creature is pushed to one side of the wall (you choose which side).

Nothing can physically pass through the wall except for creatures you designate. It has {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to all damage, as the petals instantaneously heal any hole that would be created by an attack or effect. This wall lasts for a number of minutes equal to your Druid level or until you dismiss it early (no action required).
Once you create the petal barrier, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Winds of Revival
entries: The spirit of Obojima comes to your aid in times of greatest need. When you are reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, you instead regain a number of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to half your {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} maximum and are lifted to your feet amidst a turbulent tempest of petals.

You can then immediately take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to send a wave of concussive wind sweeping out from you. Each creature in a 10-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from you must make a Strength saving throw against your Druid spell save DC. On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 2d8} Slashing damage and is pushed 15 feet away from you.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Spirit-Fused Fighter
entries: Even the life of a spirit must come to an end.

Those who take on the moniker of a Spirit-Fused Fighter do not normally do so by choice but rather by circumstance. To become a Spirit-Fused Fighter, you must first become the vessel of a dying spirit—a process that can't be sought after willingly, as no one truly understands how or why this occurs.

All that is known is that the spirit's mind and body have passed on, and its essence now coexists within the Fighter, granting them abilities beyond those of a normal spirit. Those who harness this power can channel its latent energy into objects, which produce a magical quirk or powerful attacks. These arcane tricks are how these unconventional warriors fight and are the reason they have garnered so much attention and interest on the island.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Quirk
entries: As the host of a powerful spirit, the magic within you can be strange and unruly. Though you've learned to control your powers, the arcane energy can still spark to life, often creating strange effects.
Choose one or more of the Arcane Quirks listed below:

items: When activating any feature from this subclass, First Age technology around you begins to go haywire.
Whenever you make an attack roll with a weapon or an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB}, a radio or cassette player on your person plays a snippet of a song.
Whenever you take damage, you cough bubbles.
Spirits find your odor to be incredibly off-putting.
Spirits find your odor to be incredibly attractive.
While you have the {@condition Unconscious|XPHB} condition, your body floats 1 foot off the ground and can be carried by the wind.

Whenever you score a {@variantrule Critical Hit|XPHB} against a creature, your head randomly transforms into a strange visage (such as an anthropomorphic pig head, a crimson-skinned version of yourself with flaming locks, the face of an Urugama, or a CRT TV). This transformation lasts until you transform again or finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Essence
entries: You gain the ability to channel spirit energy into your attacks. You have four Essence Dice, which are d6s. When you make an attack roll using a weapon or an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB} against a creature, you can expend an Essence Die and roll it. Add the number rolled to the attack roll or damage roll (your choice). You can choose to do this either before or after making the attack roll.

You regain all expended Essence Dice when you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You gain an additional Essence Die when you reach Fighter levels 7 (five dice total), 10 (six dice total), 15 (seven dice total), and 18 (eight dice total).

subclassFeature.name: Object Channeling
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Salvage|ObojimaTallGrass24} skill. In addition, you gain the ability to channel your internal spirit energy into objects, creating an array of effects. You learn one {@filter Channeling Option|optionalfeatures|source=|feature type=co|prerequisite=sor%3d1} of your choice from the "Channeling Options" section later in this subclass's description. You also gain an object of your choice that you can use to channel the option through.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Spirit Battery
entries: You also gain the Spirit creature type, and you learn the {@spell Jolt|ObojimaTallGrass24} cantrip. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for it. When you target a machine with the spell, the machine is powered for 1 hour instead of 18 seconds.

Additionally, once on each of your turns when you hit a target with an attack roll using a weapon or an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB} as part of the {@action Attack|XPHB} action, you can replace the attack's damage with that of the {@spell Jolt|ObojimaTallGrass24} cantrip. When you do so, you roll the Jolt cantrip's damage dice (which deals Lightning damage) instead of the weapon's damage dice; you don't gain any additional benefits to the attack's damage from other features or effects.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Object Channeling
entries: You learn another {@filter Channeling Option|optionalfeatures|source=|feature type=co|prerequisite=sor%3d1} of your choice. You can now use your {@subclassFeature Object Channeling|Fighter|XPHB|Spirit-Fused|ObojimaTallGrass24|3} feature a number of times equal to 1 plus your Constitution modifier (minimum of twice). You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Improvised Armor
entries: You learn to channel your energy into objects you are wearing, causing them to become harder than steel for a brief moment. When you are hit by an attack roll, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to expend one {@subclassFeature Channel Essence|Fighter|XPHB|Spirit-Fused|ObojimaTallGrass24|3|Essence Die} and add the number rolled to your AC against that attack, potentially causing it to miss you.

subclassFeature.name: Backup Battery
entries: You learn to draw on the spirit energy within you to gain a quick rush of energy. You gain an additional use of your {@classFeature Second Wind|Fighter|XPHB|1} (5 uses total). In addition, when your {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} drop below a number equal to your Fighter level, you can use your Second Wind immediately (no action required).

subclassFeature.name: Junk Master
entries: You learn another {@filter Channeling Option|optionalfeatures|source=|feature type=co|prerequisite=sor%3d1} of your choice. In addition, when you roll {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB}, you regain expended uses of your {@subclassFeature Object Channeling|Fighter|XPHB|Spirit-Fused|ObojimaTallGrass24|3} feature until you have two if you have fewer than that.

subclassFeature.name: Sheep Dragon Shepherd
entries: The sheep dragon is often regarded as the epitome of goodness and authenticity on the island. These creatures are dedicated to freedom and unwavering kinship. Those shepherds who live and train among the wandering sheep dragons learn to care deeply for those around them and understand how a flock works together to overcome obstacles. They must be ready to flee to safety yet know when to defend their herd. The role of a Sheep Dragon Shepherd requires resilience, compassion, and a kind heart. Because of this, these Monks are regarded by the people of Obojima as heroic—sometimes even mythic—figures.

entries.name: Historic Past
entries: As the tale goes, the first Sheep Dragon Shepherd was a wind spirit who went by the name Ventu. The spirit lived among the grass and called all that grazed the central fields of Obojima their friend. Of those creatures, none pleased Ventu more than the playful sheep dragon. In time, Ventu and the sheep dragon became inseparable. The seasons would speed away, and still the pair would frolic and parade the Gale Fields with careless glee. It was during this time that people say Ventu gifted the sheep dragon the ability to fly and control the winds.

One day, as Ventu explored the fields, they noticed something unsettling in the distance: a great pillar of black smoke split the horizon in two. Ventu rushed across the rolling hills, only to be met by terrible disaster. A raging fire had scorched the southern fields and was slowly crawling northward. Ventu, heartbroken at the thought of what might become of the sheep dragon just beyond the hillside, made the heroic choice to stand against the inferno on their own.
To this day, it's unknown what became of Ventu, but the majestic sheep dragon stands as a testament to their kindness and bravery.

subclassFeature.name: Herding Sheep
entries: You gain proficiency with {@item Shepherd Crook|ObojimaTallGrass24|Shepherd Crooks} if you don't already have it, and they are considered to have the {@itemProperty L|XPHB|Light} property for you. You also gain the ability to herd your allies, calling them closer or moving them out of danger. As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can spend 1 or more {@classFeature Monk's Focus|Monk|XPHB|2|XPHB|Focus Points} to cause a willing creature you can see within 60 feet of you to move toward you or in any other direction. This movement doesn't provoke {@action Opportunity Attack|XPHB|Opportunity Attacks}. If the creature moves toward you, it can move up to 15 feet per Focus Point spent; if it moves in any other direction, it can move up to 10 feet per Focus Point spent. A creature can't move in this way more than a number of feet equal to its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}.
The number of creatures you can target with this ability increases when you reach Monk levels 6 (2 creatures), 11 (3 creatures), and 17 (4 creatures).

subclassFeature.name: Wind Shot
entries: You gain the ability to mimic the sheep dragon's Wind Pistol, blasting enemies with powerful gale forces at a distance. Whenever you would make an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB}, you can instead choose to make a special ranged attack, firing a compressed blast of air from your mouth. This attack has a range of 60 feet and uses the same attack bonus and damage die as your {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB}.

Additionally, when you hit a target with this special attack, you can choose to spend 1 {@classFeature Monk's Focus|Monk|XPHB|2|XPHB|Focus Point} to force the target to make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the target is pushed 10 feet away from you or has the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition (your choice).

subclassFeature.name: Intercepting Maneuver
entries: Your protective nature manifests as moments of skillful deflection to aid a nearby ally. When an ally within 10 feet of you is hit by an attack roll, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} and spend 1 Focus Point to reduce the damage it takes by an amount equal to one roll of your {@classFeature Martial Arts|Monk|XPHB|1|XPHB|Martial Arts Die} plus your Dexterity modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Take to the Skies
entries: You've mastered a unique technique that lets you glide on the wind, just like a majestic sheep dragon. Whenever you use {@classFeature Monk's Focus|Monk|XPHB|2|XPHB|Step of the Wind}, you also gain a {@variantrule Fly Speed|XPHB} equal to your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} until the end of your turn.

Additionally, when you use Step of the Wind, you can simultaneously take both the {@action Disengage|XPHB} and {@action Dash|XPHB} actions without expending a {@classFeature Monk's Focus|Monk|XPHB|2|XPHB|Focus Point}.

subclassFeature.name: Guide to the Herd
entries: Your vigilant watch over your companions while in the midst of combat allows you to give them cues on when to raise their defenses. Whenever you use {@classFeature Monk's Focus|Monk|XPHB|2|XPHB|Patient Defence} to take both the {@action Disengage|XPHB} and {@action Dodge|XPHB} actions, you can spend 1 additional {@classFeature Monk's Focus|Monk|XPHB|2|XPHB|Focus Point} to share that benefit with your allies. Each ally within 30 feet of you who can see or hear you can immediately take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to also gain the benefits of the {@action Disengage|XPHB} and {@action Dodge|XPHB} actions until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of the River
entries: Those who commit themselves to the Oath of the River have found guidance in the shifting waters and the great creatures that live within them. These diverse individuals model their lives and the tenets they follow after the tranquil waters of a blue pool and the rushing rapids that spill over a great waterfall—always striving to flow around obstacles if possible, but ready to crash through them when left with no other option. As the river flows and bends, it seeks the path of least resistance on its journey to the ocean. Like the river, Paladins who have sworn this oath remain adaptable but steadfast in their own course.
These Paladins share the following tenets:

items: Forgiveness can be as sharp as any blade.
Judgment is reserved for those truly deserving of it.
If I must battle, I will fight with all my passion and strength.
I will not abandon my duty, especially when others are counting on me.

entries.name: Historic Mythos
entries: If the stories passed down by generations of Paladins are true, the first of the noble warriors and sages to dedicate themselves to the Tenets of the River did so only after speaking with the four great river spirits: Din, Yon, Mu, and Go. As the story goes, the warrior traveled across Obojima and into the domains of the great rivers, where they spent many years as the river spirits' yoriki. When the time came for the warrior to leave, they asked the four great river spirits to each bestow a piece of wisdom they could take back to the Physical Realm. The words spoken by the spirits would go on to shape the Tenets of the River.

entries.name: River Shrine
entries: River Shrines—or River Graves, as some call them—are statues erected in honor of a warrior, poet, or sage who followed the Tenets of the River. The practice is less common than it once was, but during the Human Age, when the first groups of humans began to practice them, it was customary to create statues for the most impactful adherents. These statues often depict aquatic creatures, serving as symbolic representations of how the deceased lived their lives.

entries.name: Bladeless
entries: As the Tenets of the River became more widely known, the trend of the bladeless warrior began to emerge. These paladins, unlike other swordsmen, sought to follow their beliefs without the use of a weapon. This way of thinking naturally lent itself to a slower, more contemplative lifestyle, which is why most attribute the founding of the Western River Shrine and the northern temples to the bladeless warriors.

subclassFeature.name: Blessed Pool
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can speak gentle yet courageous words that encourage your allies and heal them. Choose a number of creatures up to twice your Charisma modifier (minimum of 2) that you can see within 30 feet of you. Each target regains {@dice 2d6} {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}. Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of the River Spells
entries: The magic of your oath ensures you always have certain spells ready; when you reach a Paladin level specified in the Oath of the River Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

subclassFeature.name: Rushing Rapids
entries: As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can expend one use of your {@classFeature Channel Divinity|Paladin|XPHB|3} to cause a forceful wave of water to erupt outward in a 20-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from you. Each Large or smaller creature of your choice in the area must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be pushed to an unoccupied space that is 5 feet outside the area.

subclassFeature.name: Aura of the River
entries: You emanate an aura that causes the area around you to feel as if wading through a body of water, slowing down your enemies as they approach. The area within your {@classFeature Aura of Protection|Paladin|XPHB|6} is {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB} for other creatures. You can designate any number of creatures you can see to be unaffected by it (no action required).

In addition, the first time you hit a Large or smaller creature on your turn with a melee attack roll, you can use your aura to move the target up to 10 feet to a space you choose, provided it's unoccupied.

subclassFeature.name: Shielding Spirit
entries: Whenever you make a Dexterity saving throw, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to halve any damage you would take from the effect. When you do so, you can also expend a spell slot to extend this benefit to nearby allies. Choose a number of creatures within 10 feet of you equal to the level of the spell slot expended; the damage is also halved for each of those creatures.

subclassFeature.name: Form of the River
entries: You can manifest the powerful visage of the river spirit around your body. As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you gain the following benefits for 1 minute:

items: Your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} increases by 15 feet, and you gain a {@variantrule Swim Speed|XPHB} of 60 feet.
You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on all saving throws.
Whenever you successfully move a creature with your {@subclassFeature Aura of the River|Paladin|XPHB|River|ObojimaTallGrass24|7||aura}, you can choose to deal {@damage 2d8} Bludgeoning damage to it.

entries: Once you use this {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also restore your use of it by expending a level 5 spell slot (no action required).

subclassFeature.name: Corrupted Ranger
entries: You have become afflicted by the mysterious illness that haunts the island, known as the Corruption. This same foul magic, which has stained the coastlines black, now resides within your body. It curses your skin and seeps from your pores, and in time, it will even become difficult to distinguish you from it.

How this has happened is your story to tell. You may have been one of the first responders to the Corruption when it came to the shores of Obojima, leaving you to possibly be the only survivor of that brave band of Rangers. Or perhaps you were an explorer who stumbled upon a pocket of Corruption and became infected or maybe you were afflicted by the Corruption due to an evil Witch's curse.

However this fate has befallen you, you are now both cursed and empowered by the Corruption's rotting, withering magic that is slowly taking over you bit by bit, replacing your own flesh with its unearthly power.
As a corrupted being, you must choose your future wisely. It's hard to say what this illness will manifest in you.

entries.name: Side-Effects Caused by the Corruption

items: Bursts of Anger

entries: You have sudden and passionate bursts of anger caused by moments of adrenaline.

items: Below the Depths

entries: A thick steam begins to ripple off of your body when you've been gravely injured. The effects leave your clothing drenched and smelling of seawater.

items: Withered Lungs

entries: You can't help but cough blood throughout your day.

items: Flavorless

entries: You've lost the ability to taste.

items: Sleepless Nights

entries: More often than not, you spend your nights awake, plagued by your illness.

items: Vertigo

entries: The strong and sudden sensation of the world spinning around you comes on at a moment's notice. You're unsure as to what causes it, but it can be debilitating.

subclassFeature.name: First Manifestation
entries: Whenever you take damage, you also receive a curse marker; if the damage was from a {@variantrule Critical Hit|XPHB}, you receive two curse markers instead. These markers remain active until the end of your next turn. The maximum number of curse markers you can have at a time is 2. When you hit a creature with an attack roll using a weapon or an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB}, all curse markers you have are consumed, dealing an extra {@damage 1d4} Necrotic damage to the target for each curse marker consumed.
Alternatively, you can take a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to call upon your corruption, immediately gaining curse markers until you have your maximum.
Your maximum number of curse markers increases when you reach Ranger levels 5 (3 markers total), 11 (4 markers total), and 17 (5 markers total).

subclassFeature.name: Second Manifestation
entries: When you make a Strength or Dexterity check, you can choose to replace the result with a number equal to 10 plus your Ranger level. You can wait until after you roll the {@dice d20} before deciding to use this feature, but you must decide before the GM says whether the roll succeeds or fails. You can use this feature twice, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Third Manifestation
entries: When you make an attack roll using a weapon or an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB} against a creature, you can expend one {@subclassFeature First Manifestation|Ranger|XPHB|Corrupted|ObojimaTallGrass24|3|ObojimaTallGrass24|curse marker} to roll a {@dice d4} and add it to the roll. You can choose to use a curse marker in this way before or after making the attack roll. You can expend a curse marker in this way only once per turn.

Additionally, whenever you take damage, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to reduce the damage taken by an amount equal to your Ranger level. Once you reduce damage in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Fourth Manifestation
entries: Your ailment is beginning to have side effects on your body. You gain one ailment of your choice, as described below.

entries.name: Failing Lungs
entries: Your lungs have begun to ache, and at times you feel yourself gasping for air. As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you pull your next breath from a creature you can see. The target can't take {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB|Reactions} until the start of your next turn, and if it is Large or smaller, it has the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition. Additionally, all of your curse markers are consumed, dealing {@damage 1d4} Necrotic damage to the target per curse marker.

Alternatively, you can give your breath to another creature. Whenever a creature you can see makes a Dexterity saving throw, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to give it {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on the save and increase its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} by 15 feet until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Graying Vision
entries: The world around you begins to lose some of its colorful luster. You gain {@sense Blindsight|XPHB} with a range of 15 feet. In addition, you automatically detect visual illusions you can see if the DC for the Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check to discern them is less than or equal to your Ranger spell save DC.

entries.name: Losing Feeling
entries: Your hands and arms burn with a cold, ethereal flame that only you can see. As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can target a creature you can see within 60 feet of you, enveloping it with the same cursed flames. When you deal damage with your curse markers to a creature enveloped by these flames, each {@subclassFeature First Manifestation|Ranger|XPHB|Corrupted|ObojimaTallGrass24|3|ObojimaTallGrass24|curse marker} deals {@damage 1d6} Necrotic damage instead of {@dice 1d4}.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Fifth Manifestation
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can gain the following benefits until the start of your next turn:

items: Your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is doubled.
You gain a +2 bonus to AC.
You can make two additional attacks if you take the {@action Attack|XPHB} action.
All of your attacks are treated as if you have your maximum number of {@subclassFeature First Manifestation|Ranger|XPHB|Corrupted|ObojimaTallGrass24|3|ObojimaTallGrass24|curse markers}.

entries: If you use this feature a second time before finishing a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, in addition to the effects wearing off at the start of your next turn, you also gain 1 {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level and immediately drop to 1 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} if you have more than that at the start of your turn.
Once you use this feature a second time, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Waxwork Rogue
entries: Waxwork Rogues have a long history on Obojima of dealing with the dangerous and the arcane. They're known for having an array of tools and tricks to delve into the most perilous places—and almost always return with treasures and tales. To a Waxwork Rogue, any challenge can be solved with a bit of wax, a pinch of smarts, and a whole lot of magic.

The Waxwork Rogue offers a blend of arcane manipulation and roguish cunning, making them far more than just skilled thieves. Their abilities stem from an arcane heritage deeply tied to witchcraft. Waxwork Rogues learn unique enchantments that allow them to craft magical candles with diverse effects—from healing allies and detecting spirits to conjuring flammable wax barriers or wielding a whip of pure flame. This versatility allows them to serve as infiltrators, investigators, and even battlefield controllers, always adapting to challenges with their peculiar brand of wax-and-fire magic.

entries.name: In the Beginning
entries: The Courier Brigade was created to carry packages between villages and guard merchant wagons through treacherous areas. But there are some areas on Obojima that are rife with the arcane, spirit dangers, and uncanny occurrences.

Legend says that it was Lydia Starwright, Courier Brigade First Class, who—against all advice—sought out the aid of a powerful witch who was rumored to live within a hut of melted wax deep within the Land of Hot Water. It was there, in that melted hut, that the witch taught Lydia the arcane practices known only to certain spirits of the island, the ability to enchant wax and fire in wondrous ways. This knowledge transformed Lydia into the first Waxwork Rogue.

Lydia brought back this knowledge to the Courier Brigade and formed the Waxworks Division, a dedicated group of arcane Rogues who volunteered for the most perilous assignments and deliveries of the Courier Brigade.
In the present day, Waxwork Rogues have transcended the ranks of the Courier Brigade, and their skills are practiced across the island.

subclassFeature.name: Conjure Flame
entries: You know the {@spell Dancing Lights|XPHB} cantrip (the lights appear as floating candles) and the {@spell Produce Flame|XPHB} cantrip. Your spellcasting ability for these spells is Intelligence or Charisma (choose when you gain this feature).

subclassFeature.name: Wax Enchantments
entries: You have the ability to pull and manipulate magic from the Spirit Realm. You learn wax enchantments that are fueled by a special resource called Wick Points.

entries.name: Enchantments
entries: You learn four enchantments of your choice from the "Enchantment Options" section below. You learn two additional enchantments of your choice when you reach Rogue levels 9, 13, and 17. Each time you learn new enchantments, you can also replace one enchantment you know with a different one.

entries.name: Wick Points
entries: You have 3 Wick Points. Your maximum number of Wick Points increases by 1 whenever you gain a Rogue level.
When you expend a Wick Point, it is unavailable until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, at the end of which you regain all your expended points.

subclassFeature.name: Burn Cycle
entries: You can ignite your weapons in a flash of white-hot flames when you successfully catch an enemy off guard. When you use your {@classFeature Sneak Attack|Rogue|XPHB|1} on your turn, you can expend {@subclassFeature Wax Enchantments|Rogue|XPHB|Waxwork|ObojimaTallGrass24|3|ObojimaTallGrass24|Wick Points} in place of Sneak Attack dice whenever you use a {@classFeature Cunning Strike|Rogue|XPHB|5} effect. You must expend 1 Wick Point per Sneak Attack die you would normally have to forgo. When you expend Wick Points in this way, you can also change the damage type of your Sneak Attack damage to Fire for that attack.

subclassFeature.name: Advanced Enchantments
entries: Some of your enchantments become more potent; refer to the enhanced effects below. If you haven't learned any of the following enchantments, you learn one of them as part of this feature.

entries.name: {@optfeature Blooming Light|ObojimaTallGrass24}
entries: The effects of Blooming Light last for 8 hours, instead of 1 hour.

entries.name: {@optfeature Bocha Glue Wax|ObojimaTallGrass24}
entries: The DC for the Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check to break the bond early increases to 20.

entries.name: {@optfeature Burning Delay|ObojimaTallGrass24}
entries: You can now delay the effects of the specified enchantments by 1 round, 3 rounds, 1 minute, 10 minutes, or 1 hour.

entries.name: {@optfeature Candle Pop|ObojimaTallGrass24}
entries: Candle Pop affects the target and each creature within 5 feet of it.

entries.name: {@optfeature Delicacy|ObojimaTallGrass24}
entries: The creature regains {@dice 1d12} {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} instead of {@dice 1d6}, and you can have up to four candles with this enchantment at a time instead of two.

entries.name: {@optfeature Iron Seal|ObojimaTallGrass24}
entries: The DC for the Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check to break the seal increases to 20.

entries.name: {@optfeature Maker's Mark|ObojimaTallGrass24}
entries: Maker's Mark now deals Bludgeoning damage equal to {@dice 1d6} plus your Dexterity modifier, plus an extra {@damage 1d10} Fire damage.

entries.name: {@optfeature Shielding Seal|ObojimaTallGrass24}
entries: You can have up to 3 Shielding Seals active at a time instead of 1.

entries.name: {@optfeature Waxlings|ObojimaTallGrass24}
entries: As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can create two Waxlings simultaneously by spending 3 Wick Points instead of 2.

subclassFeature.name: Spirit Flame
entries: You learn to craft a special candle made of pink wax. As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can ignite this candle, which burns for 1 minute. While the burning candle is on your person, you gain the following benefits:

items: The {@subclassFeature Wax Enchantments|Rogue|XPHB|Waxwork|ObojimaTallGrass24|3|ObojimaTallGrass24|Wick Point} cost of your enchantments is reduced by 1.
You have {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to Fire damage.
Spirits have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on attack rolls against you.
The candle can't be extinguished by nonmagical means.

entries: Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Oni Kin Sorcery
entries: In the realm of magic, there exists a lineage of Sorcerers whose blood bears an ancient connection to the oni. These Sorcerers, known as Oni Kin, harness the magic of their lineage to weave powerful spells. But as they delve deeper into their arcane abilities, they find themselves gradually transforming—both physically and spiritually—into embodiments of the oni's fearsome might.

At the outset of their journey and as they use their powers, Oni Kin begin to see subtle manifestations of their lineage: changes in appearance and temperament. However, as they channel their magic with greater skill, these traits begin to intensify. Their skin may change, their eyes may glow with an eerie light, and their once-subtle features may become more pronounced, bearing the unmistakable visage of an oni.

As their power reaches its zenith, Oni Kin reach a pinnacle where they can fully embrace their heritage and assume the form of a true oni. In this form, they stand as towering figures of terror, wielding unparalleled magical might and physical prowess. Yet with this transformation comes a perilous temptation—the struggle to maintain control over the oni's insatiable hunger for chaos and destruction. This struggle does not go unnoticed by islanders, most of whom fear or distrust the Oni Kin.

subclassFeature.name: Oni Spells
entries: When you reach a Sorcerer level specified in the Oni Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

rows: {@spell Charm Person}, {@spell Spell Signature|ObojimaTallGrass24}, {@spell Swallow Magic|ObojimaTallGrass24}, {@spell Transparency|ObojimaTallGrass24}

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Prison
entries: Trapped inside you is the essence of the first oni, passed down through its children and stretched across a long and treacherous lineage. As you grow in power, so does the spirit within you. It desperately wishes to bubble to the surface, and it does so when you're at your weakest. You gain the traits of the oni, which manifest as you expend {@classFeature Font of Magic|Sorcerer|XPHB|2|XPHB|Sorcery Points}. Each oni trait becomes available to you based on how many Sorcery Points you're missing from your total, as detailed in the table below. Regaining Sorcery Points can cause you to lose one or more oni traits.
Each oni trait has both a physical manifestation and an arcane effect, which last until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} or otherwise lose the trait.

entries.name: Oni traits
entries: The traits are presented in the order they manifest, from least {@classFeature Font of Magic|Sorcerer|XPHB|2|XPHB|Sorcery Points} missing to most.

entries.name: Eyes
entries: Your eyes shimmer with an almost mesmerizing quality. As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can activate your innate ocular charm. For 1 minute, you have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on all Charisma checks directed at one creature of your choice that isn't {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward you, provided it can see your eyes. When the effect ends, the creature must make a Wisdom saving throw against your Sorcerer spell save DC. On a success, the target realizes that you used magic to influence its mood and becomes {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward you. A creature prone to violence might attack you. Another creature might seek retribution in a different way (at the GM's discretion), depending on the nature of your interaction.

entries.name: Horns
entries: Horns rapidly sprout from your head. When you cast a cantrip that requires you to make a melee or ranged spell attack, you can instead make a melee spell attack using your horns, channeling the spell through them. When you hit a creature with a cantrip cast in this way, the target takes an extra {@damage 1d6} Piercing damage.

Additionally, when a creature provokes an {@action Opportunity Attack|XPHB} from you by leaving your reach, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to cast a cantrip at the creature using your horns, rather than making an {@action Opportunity Attack|XPHB}. The spell must have a casting time of an action and must target only that creature.

entries.name: Skin
entries: Your skin turns a dull red, green, or blue color (your choice), and you adopt the regenerative powers of the oni. Whenever you cast a spell of level 1 or higher, you regain a number of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the spell's level plus your Constitution modifier. You don't gain this benefit if you have the Tongue trait active during that casting.

entries.name: Tongue
entries: With every incantation you cast, the twisted and demonic voice of the first oni can be heard within your speech. When you cast a spell that has a Verbal component and targets a single creature, you can also take a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to cause the target to recoil in fear. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw against your Sorcerer spell save DC. On a failed save, the target either has the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition or it must immediately use its {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}, if available, to move up to half its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} away from you (your choice).

entries.name: Hair
entries: Your hair turns a shocking white and stretches towards the ground as it grows to cover your back. You gain a +2 bonus to AC.

subclassFeature.name: Ogre Manipulation
entries: You can manifest {@subclassFeature Arcane Prison|Sorcerer|XPHB|Oni Kin|ObojimaTallGrass24|3|ObojimaTallGrass24|oni traits} regardless of how many {@classFeature Font of Magic|Sorcerer|XPHB|2|XPHB|Sorcery Points} you're missing. As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can activate one of the oni traits you currently have access to, drawing it out early. When activated in this way, the trait lasts for 1 minute, and you lose it if you haven't gained the trait by normal means within that time.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Boiling Power
entries: Your {@subclassFeature Arcane Prison|Sorcerer|XPHB|Oni Kin|ObojimaTallGrass24|3|ObojimaTallGrass24|oni traits} grow in power. The following changes apply to your traits.

entries.name: Eyes
entries: In addition to the trait's normal benefits, you have the {@spell Zone of Truth|XPHB} spell prepared, which you can cast without expending a spell slot. When cast in this way, only one creature of your choice within 60 feet of you that can see your eyes is affected. The target repeats its save against the spell at the start of each of its turns; the spell ends early if the target can no longer see your eyes.

entries.name: Horns
entries: The extra damage dealt by your horns increases to {@dice 1d12}.

entries.name: Skin
entries: Whenever you cast a spell of level 1 or higher, you now regain a number of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to twice the spell's level plus your Constitution modifier.

entries.name: Tongue
entries: When you activate the Tongue trait using a spell slot of level 5 or higher, instead of the trait's normal effects, you can cause the target to tremble in fear, becoming hyperfixated on you. The target's {@variantrule Passive Perception|XPHB} is reduced to 5 and it takes a -5 penalty to its AC against all attacks not made by you. This effect lasts until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Transformation
entries: You can fully embody the fabled visage of your demon ancestor without needing to exhaust your sorcerous power. As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can instantly manifest all of your {@subclassFeature Arcane Prison|Sorcerer|XPHB|Oni Kin|ObojimaTallGrass24|3|ObojimaTallGrass24|oni traits}, regardless of how many {@classFeature Font of Magic|Sorcerer|XPHB|2|XPHB|Sorcery Points} you're missing. While manifesting your oni traits in this way, you have {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Bludgeoning, Piercing, and Slashing damage, and you have {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} and {@condition Frightened|XPHB} conditions.

This effect lasts for 1 minute, after which you lose any trait you haven't gained by normal means in that time. Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, unless you spend 5 Sorcery Points (no action required) to restore your use of it.

subclassFeature.name: Lantern Patron
entries: Warlocks who make a pact with a powerful spirit are able to tap into the magic that flows through the Spirit Realm. These Warlocks are known by the special lanterns they carry—lanterns that burn with the essence of their patron. The illumination of this vessel carries the attributes of the spirit, granting the Warlock an array of abilities.

When spirits enter pacts with people, there is often more to it than generosity. Spirits powerful enough to lend out bits of their magic do so for a variety of reasons. Perhaps the spirit is bound by a bargain or curse. It could be that the spirit needs allies (though they might not readily admit it). Or maybe they simply see something in you that amuses them. The things that motivate spirits are as varied as the spirits themselves—and truly powerful spirits can be inscrutable.

subclassFeature.name: Lantern Spells
entries: The magic of your patron ensures you always have certain spells ready; when you reach a Warlock level specified in the Lantern Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

rows: {@spell Faerie Fire}, {@spell Identify}, {@spell Locate Object}, {@spell Swallow Magic|ObojimaTallGrass24}
{@spell Create Spirit Train Stop|ObojimaTallGrass24}, {@spell Tamh Gon's Fiery Festival Feast|ObojimaTallGrass24}

subclassFeature.name: Illuminating Aura
entries: The essence of your spirit patron is channeled into a lantern, where it appears as a minor form of itself. You can use your lantern as a {@variantrule Spellcasting Focus|XPHB} for your Warlock spells.

As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can activate your lantern, causing it to shed {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} in a 20-foot radius and {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB} for an additional 20 feet. This light lasts for 1 minute, until you let go of the lantern, or until you choose to end the effect early (no action required). For the duration, you gain the following benefits:

items: Whenever you see a creature in your lantern's {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} make a saving throw, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to grant that creature a bonus to the roll equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of +1).
Whenever an enemy within your lantern's {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB} fails a saving throw, it takes Radiant damage equal to half your Warlock level (round up).

entries: Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Revealing Light
